FACULTY CALLED TO WAR WORK
Members Rendering Invaluable Service
to Government — Enlistment of Drs.
Watson and Dunlap Postpones
Studies in Psychology.

The effects of the call to war
have made themselves quite as evident among the Johns Hopkins
faculty as among the student body.
The teaching force in many departments is sadly depleted as a result of the departure of valuable
men, and several professors who
have not actually left the University are devoting a large part of
their time to war work.
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, professor
of physics, who has recently re- .
turned from his important mission
in Europe,and Dr. H. F. Reid, professor, of dynamic geology and geography, are members of an investigation committee appointed by
President Wilson and working in
conjunction with the National Research Council. Charles J. Tilden,
professor of civil engineering, has
been appointed captain in the Engineer Corps; whereas Carl C. Thomas, firofessor of mechanical engineering, and Dr. B. Whitehead,
professor of electrical engineering,
have been commissioned majors in
the same branch of the service.
Dr. W. W. Willoughby, professor of political science, is in the
service of the Institute of Government Research. Dr. John B. Watson, professor of experimental and
comparative psychology, and Dr.
Knight Dunlap, professor of experimental psychology, have been
appointed major and captain, respectively, in the Medical Research. Bureau, in connection with
the Aviation Corps; they are in
charge of the examination and selection of prospective aviators.
The work of the Department of
Psychology will be indefinitely
postponed through the loss of
these men.
Dr. Ralph V. D. Magoffin, associate professor of Greek and Roman history, has been commissioned captain in the Quartermaster Corps; he is now stationed at
Camp Jackson, Columbia, S. C.
Prof. Robert Wood has been
made major in the Signal Corps
and is now working in France.
Dr. W. F. Shenton, instructor in
mathematics, has accepted a position at the Naval Academy at Annapolis.
Lieut. Charles W.• Elliott, collegiate professor of military science and tactics, has been commissioned Captain in the Regular
Army and assigned to the camp
at Gettysburg. Sergt. Albert
Friedlander, instructor in military

J. H. U. MEN IN MANY BRANCHES
Over 200 Are Engaged in War Service
Forty Received Commissions al
Fort Myer.— Complete List
Being Prepared.

Over 200 Johns Hopkins men
from among the faculty, undergraduates and graduates of very
recent date alone are now engaged
in war service. Not only has the
entire upper-class body been reduced to, a mere fraction of its
original size, but many vacancies
that will be difficult—if possible
at all—to fill entirely, have been
left among the faculty.
The enlistment records of the
Registrar's office are necessarily
incomplete as regards graduates
of anything except recent date,
but concerning the latter the list
is practically complete. It shows
men of every rank in practically
every branch of the service. A
large percentage of the number
are commissioned officers.
Of the men receiving commissions in the June officers' training
camp at Fort Meyer, Va., over 40
were Johns Hopkins men, with
ranks ranging from second lieutenant to major. The number was
about equally divided among the
different branches of service. Several Hopkins men were also
among those who received commissions from other officers' training
camps. Thirteen were appointed
at about the same time as officers
in the Regular Army.
Thirteen Hopkins men are in the
Naval Militia, ten in the Naval
Reserve, three in the Maryland infantry, five in aviation and three
in the coast artillery. The Maryland Battalion of Field Artillery
has twenty-five J. H. U. men on
its roster. Nineteen are in the
Ambulance Corps. Several more
have entered different branches of
the Canadian and British armies.
THE NEWS-LETTER expects to
publish in an early issue as complete a list of the Johns Hopkins
men who have entered as it is possible to obtain at the present time.

The time-honored tradition of
the annual Hullabaloo, published
by the Senior Class, promises to
be broken this year. The chances
of the publishing of a 1918 Hullabaloo will be seen to be slight
when it is remembered that five of
the seven editors, including the
editor-in-chief and the business
manager, are in some branch of
the service, and that hardly more
than a fifth of the Class of 1918
has returned to the University.
R. R. Duncan, editor-in-chief, is
a sergeant in the Maryland Battalion of Field Artillery stationed
at Anniston, Ala., where are also
Stuart Egerton and W. Jacobson.
Henry Evans, business manager,is
with an ambulance unit in France,
and Paul Wiggins, art editor, is in
the Officers' Reserve Corps. Only
Wolfe and Rothschild, the remaining members of the board, have returned to the University.
The Senior Class will probably
meet in the near future and take
some definite action in regard to a
class book. To organize an entirely
new business and editorial staff
at this late date seems highly improbable and most impracticable.
However, some substitute for the
Hullabaloo will more than likely
be adopted. It may be that a
much less elaborate book than the
traditional Hullabaloo will be approved, or it may be found possible to co-operate with THE NEWSLETTER in the publishing of the
most essential features of a Hullabaloo.

The organization of this year's
track team will take place at a
mass-meeting for athletics to be
held in the Civil Engineering
Building this Wednesday at 12.30
o'clock, at which time the plans
and prospects for one of the most
ambitious schedules the team has
ever had to carry out will be discussed by Coach Joseph T. England, Captain Firor and the
manager.
On the same day the fall practice will commence on Straus
Field at 5 o'clock. This will comprise cross country runs and preliminary work on the hurdles. The
cross country course has been completely laid out and flagged and
will be in good condition for use.
A big field day of fourteen regular
events is being planned as the
culmination of fall training.
The schedule starts off with the
S. A. A. cross country meet on
Thanksgiving Day. In it Hopkins
will probably compete with teams
representing Virginia, Washington and Lee, Virginia Polytechnic
Institute and Catholic University
of Washington, D. C. Georgetown
University may also enter men.
Following this will occur the
two Washington indoor meets—
those of George Washington and
Georgetown Universities. Also in
mid-winter the big Hopkins-Fifth
Regiment Armory meet will take
place, in which every man on the
squad has a chance to make good.
It is expected that the S. A. A.
outdoor meet will be held on
Homewood Field the first Friday
and Saturday in May, and plans
are being made accordingly. Trips
to Washington and Lee and Haverford are likewise under consideration.
In every meet there are to be
fourteen regular events and Hopkins must have three men for each
event. Men in the longer distances
are especially needed, but Coach
England and Captain Firor are
anxious to have a large turnout
for the other events as well.
Firor, who is a first-year Student in the Medical School, hie
discovered quite a number of valuable men in that department of the
University who expect to help out
when training begins.

Currin, a literal-minded young
reporter, had been assigned to
cover a town ball. Later the city
editor was going over his copy.
"Look here, Currin," he suddenly called out. "What do you mean
by writing here,'Among the beautiful girls was Councilman Oscar
Dodge'? He isn't a 'beautiful
girl,' you dub; he's only a fat old
fusser."
"I can't help that," responded
Currin dogedly; "that's where he
was."—Ex.

COACH MURPHY NOW IN ARMY;
MAY RETURN AT CLOSE OF WAR

B.Russell Murphy, who resigned
his position as athletic director at
Johns Hopkins last August,is now
a physical director in the National
Army, with the rank of captain,
and has been placed in charge of
all physical work at Camp Lee,
Petersburg, Va. He has charge of
the fostering and organization of
athletics of all sorts among the
men.
Associated with Captain Murphy
in this work is Lieut. Edward M.
Stuart, Hopkins '17.
As he is still under contract
with the Athletic Association, it
is expected that Captain Murphy
will, at the close of the war, return to the University and resume
his duties as athletic director.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 8, 1917.
The Duty of Every Student.

Ever,‘ student attending the
University this year has responsibilities and duties more pressing
than ever before. The situation
facing him is most eloquently and
cogently described in the message
of our president, appearing on the
first page of this paper. The student must realize that he is a member of a world-famed institution
which is playing an invaluable
part in helping the Government
to bring this war to a close. It
has given its biggest men and offered all its resources to the Goveminent. The foremost of those
who are directing this country's
destinies in this present crisis are
Hopkins alumni. Every nerve of
the University is straining to
bring about world peace.
A student should, therefore, first
feel proud to have his name upon
the rolls of this University, and
should have as his crowning ambition the desire to emulate those
Hopkins men who are giving their •
best to the service of the United
States. He should realize that it
is his duty to prepare himself for
present military service or for the
later period of reconstruction.
This is to be done by first mastering his studies, and then by build-

ing up • his physical welfare
through enlistment in the corps
and participation in athletics. He
should support also, as far as his
time and ability will permit, the
other activities. He must bend all
his energies to uphold the honor
and traditions of old Hopkins, and
the new responsibilities it has assumed as a leading war-time institution.

Letters From Men at Front

It's too fast for me." They say
here in camp that there are a number of men in various companies
who came from up-State parts of
Florida and the Carolinas who
think they are in France now, and
their comrades are having lots of
fun with them.
Camp Jackson is five miles out
from Columbia and stretches
along over about four or five miles
of low sand hills. We had some
heavy rains last week and the immediate disappearance of the
water without a sign of mud
made clear the good • judgment
in the site for the camp. Conscript men are pouring in every
day, and we shall soon have
our full quota of 40,000 men. Already the raw rookies of two
weeks ago are not to be recognized. They are catching on very
quickly, and this Eighty-first Division will do itself proud.
We have the motor trucks, or
part of them, that were with
General Pershing on the Mexican
border. Ten thousand carpenters
and laborers of different sorts
come out to camp every morning
at 7 in train after train, and it is
a sight to see them pour out and
swarm off to their parts of the
camps. Just outside the camp are
both tents and barracks in which
colored workmen stay. After their
evening meal their songs and
shouts often carry as far as our
quarters. •
We are all house] very comfortably indeed, and our appetites
seem nOt to be on the decrease.
If I believed the Spartans ever
bathed—but I know I never made
such a statement in my Greek history class as that they did—I'd
claim it was Spartanic to go out
some forty yards through a 40°
temperature at 5.50 A. M. to take
a cold shower. We forget that
temperature by noon, for it is 70°
and more by then.
I've only been in town once and
that was to church last Sunday,
and then to dinner with Dr. Currell, the president of the University of South Carolina, who is an
Omicron Delta Kappa, who used
to be a professor at Washington
and Lee, where he was a close
friend of Professor Latane's. We
have a Y. M. C. A. in every regiment out here, and I'm billed for
a talk in one or another every
Monday night.
This week has been a very different one from the corresponding
October weeks I've spent the last
ten years. I feel relieved of a great
responsibility (?) in not having
to advise you and a lot of other
noble youths this autumn.
• Yours very truly,
CAPT. R. V. D. MAGOFFIN,
Asst. to Camp Q. M.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 8, 1917.
RESUMED

ROOTERS TO GO TO GETTYSBURG

Promotions on West Point Basis-220
Men Report — Provisional Officers
Appointed—Hopkins Rating Excellent—Konze Made Major.

Arrangements Made for Students to
Attend Game—Trip Through Historic
Grounds Planned — Special
Rates Secured.

The future policy of the Reserve
Officers' rraining Corps at Johns
Hopkins, with regard to promotions, will be along lines strictly
similar to that followed at West
Point, according to general orders
recently publishel through the adjutant by Captain Guild, the new
professor of military training and
tactics.
The West Point system is fundamentally based upon the division
of appointments, so that the commissioned officers are picked from
the Senior Class, the sergeants
from the juniors and the corporals
from the sophomores. Promotions
are strictly according to seniority
and efficiency. The appointments
made at the present time are provisional only, and will be retained
after December 15 only on proved
efficiency.
The following provisional appointments and assignments have
been made:
To be major—J. E. Konze.
Company A — Captain, C. H.
Baxley; first lieutenant, M. B.
Carroll; second lieutenant, N. S.
Cullum; first sergeant, L. W. Simon.
Company B — Captain, K. 0.
Bitter; first lieutenant, J. H.
Lampe; second lieutenant, H. H.
Startzman ; first sergeant, L. T.
mitt.
Company C — Captain, L. T.
Chisholm; first lieutenant, G. S.
Harris; second lieutenant, C. A.
Bryan; first sergeant, E. H. Townsend.
The non-commissioned personnel
has also been announced.
The first assembly of the corps
was held -last Thursday on the
quadrangle, when approximately
220 men reported. These will
eventually be divided into three
companies of 72 men each. A detachment of commissioned and
non-commissioned officers from the
three small companies of trained
men will be detailed as drill-masters for the new men.
Drills are set for Monday and
Thursday of each week, with optional drills to be held for the companie.; in rotation on Tuesdays.
The nature of the work taken up

Arrangements have been made
for every student of Johns Hopkins to accompany- the team to
the football game with Gettysburg
this coming Saturday. The train,
on the Western Maryland Railroad, leaves Union Station at 8
A. M., arriving in Gettysburg later
in the morning. Rooters will be
provided with banners, megaphones and other cheering paraphernalia.
Upon arrival, buses will be provided to convey all those who wish
to see the historic battleground to
the many points of interest, one being the encampment of the several
thousand soldiers who are stationed there. The majority of
these men are to attend the game.
This is the first time that Hopkins has played Gettysburg away
from Baltimore, and the contest
promises to be a good one. Special
rates have been obtained from the
railroad and the sightseeing cars
at Gettysburg, and a special admission price has been secured,
making the cost of the trip very
small.

MILITARY

TRAINING

at the latter drills will be at the
option of the students. It is expected that the work this year will
progress rapidly, hi view of the
fact that a much larger percentage
of the corps are trained men than
was the case last year.
It has been learned through an
authoritative source that the report made to the War Department
by the inspecting officer who reviewed the Hopkins troops last
spring was highly favorable. It
stated that the greatest spirit and
zeal were exhibited, that the requirements were more than met
and that the Johns Hopkins Reserve Officers' Training Corps compared more than favorably with
any in the country.
Capt. G. D. Guild, retired, the
new professor of military training
and tactics, graduated at West
Point in 1903, and was at one time
stationed in the regiment with his
predecessor here, Lieutenant Elliott, who is now serving as captain in the army.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 8, 1917.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.
All letters intended for publication must
be concise.
No attention will be paid to anonymous
letters, but names signed as an evidence of
good faith will not be printed if request is
made that they be omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to be
taken as an indorsement of its views by THE
NEWS-LETTER, which invites the freest discussion of matters of general interest.

Sophomores, Attention!
To the Editor of TIIE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—I wish to make a vigorous
protest against the attitude of the
undergraduate body of the University toward the obedience of
freshman regulations. No one
seems to know why, but there is
an indifference to all expressions
of college spirit at Hopkins this
year, which is drably discouraging. What has come over the student body? They are
they are asleep; they are dead!
And we are all being anaesthetized by that very indifference into
a dreamy state of I-should-worryness! As a result, here are the
freshmen sauntering in and out
of the main entrance to Gilman
Hall, walking across the campus,
wearing their hats with delightful
unconcern as to whether they are
indoors or out! Right now is the
time for deciding the question of
the responsibility for the enforcement of the regulations. The
trouble is that no one knows who
1$ supposed to enforce them; and
a responsibility not deliberately
and specifically imposed will not
be shouldered by anyone at'all. I
appeal to the loyalty and good
sense of the Sophomore Class to
take this matter in hand. If we
cannot make the pulse of Hopkins
spirit throb with a sense of new ••
life, we shall at least succeed in
giving the University the opportunity of copying a brand of genuine college spirit!
SOPHOMORE.
October 6, 1917.

MUSICAL CLUBS MEET TUESDAY SPIRIT SHOWN AT RECEPTION
Spieker, Will Lead Singing—Mandolin
Club Becomes Instrumental Club.
Two Out-of-Town Trips
Being Planned.

An organization meeting of the
Johns Hopkins Combined Musical
Clubs is to be held thisTuesday,
and practice will commence soon
afterwards. Manager Kellum is
trying to engage an outside man
to take charge of instruction of
the stringed instruments, and it is
hoped that a leader can be found
in the Medical School, as several
talented musicians are known to
be in that department. E. M.
Spieker, a graduate student and
former editor-in-chief, of THE
NEWS-LETTER, who has been Connected with the clubs for several
years, will have the direction of
the Glee Club.
The scope of the former Mandolin Club has been broadened to include all stringed instruments and
traps, the name being changed to
Instrumental Club.
The opportunities for new men
are considered especially good this
year, as so many of last year's
members of the Musical Clubs have
left the University, while the expert training received by members
of both clubs is considered decidedly valuable in itself.
While no definite arrangements
have as yet been made, it is probable that there will be at least
two out-of-town trips.
The Ballad of the Dean's Decree.
The Dean sent word to the students
That range the Homewood green,
And he made decree: "Give ear to me
And hearken to the Dean.
"Forbear to sleep in the gathering day
And cut your class the while;
No more let breakfast-food delay,
Nor buckwheat cakes beguile;
Nor think to loaf on all the profs,
While saying: 'I should smile.'
"Ye may weigh the down of a molting
gnat,
Or compass a comet's girth.
Determine the rule of the molecule,
Or the swing of the cycling earth.
If ye cut your class, ye shall not pass,
For what is your physics worth?

be ready to announce the dates
and subjects of the debates for the
coming year, including the traditional triangular debate and the

Johns Hopkins University make

military training. Up to that

FACULTY CALLED TO WAR WORK
Members Rendering Invaluable Service
to Government — Enlistment of Drs.
Watson and Dunlap Postpones
Studies in Psychology.

The effects of the call to war
have made themselves quite as evident among the Johns Hopkins
faculty as among the student body.
The teaching force in many departments is sadly depleted as a result of the departure of valuable
men, and several professors who
have not actually left the University are devoting a large part of
their time to war work.
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, professor
of physics, who has recently re- .
turned from his important mission
in Europe,and Dr. H. F. Reid, professor, of dynamic geology and geography, are members of an investigation committee appointed by
President Wilson and working in
conjunction with the National Research Council. Charles J. Tilden,
professor of civil engineering, has
been appointed captain in the Engineer Corps; whereas Carl C. Thomas, firofessor of mechanical engineering, and Dr. B. Whitehead,
professor of electrical engineering,
have been commissioned majors in
the same branch of the service.
Dr. W. W. Willoughby, professor of political science, is in the
service of the Institute of Government Research. Dr. John B. Watson, professor of experimental and
comparative psychology, and Dr.
Knight Dunlap, professor of experimental psychology, have been
appointed major and captain, respectively, in the Medical Research. Bureau, in connection with
the Aviation Corps; they are in
charge of the examination and selection of prospective aviators.
The work of the Department of
Psychology will be indefinitely
postponed through the loss of
these men.
Dr. Ralph V. D. Magoffin, associate professor of Greek and Roman history, has been commissioned captain in the Quartermaster Corps; he is now stationed at
Camp Jackson, Columbia, S. C.
Prof. Robert Wood has been
made major in the Signal Corps
and is now working in France.
Dr. W. F. Shenton, instructor in
mathematics, has accepted a position at the Naval Academy at Annapolis.
Lieut. Charles W.• Elliott, collegiate professor of military science and tactics, has been commissioned Captain in the Regular
Army and assigned to the camp
at Gettysburg. Sergt. Albert
Friedlander, instructor in military

J. H. U. MEN IN MANY BRANCHES
Over 200 Are Engaged in War Service
Forty Received Commissions al
Fort Myer.— Complete List
Being Prepared.

Over 200 Johns Hopkins men
from among the faculty, undergraduates and graduates of very
recent date alone are now engaged
in war service. Not only has the
entire upper-class body been reduced to, a mere fraction of its
original size, but many vacancies
that will be difficult—if possible
at all—to fill entirely, have been
left among the faculty.
The enlistment records of the
Registrar's office are necessarily
incomplete as regards graduates
of anything except recent date,
but concerning the latter the list
is practically complete. It shows
men of every rank in practically
every branch of the service. A
large percentage of the number
are commissioned officers.
Of the men receiving commissions in the June officers' training
camp at Fort Meyer, Va., over 40
were Johns Hopkins men, with
ranks ranging from second lieutenant to major. The number was
about equally divided among the
different branches of service. Several Hopkins men were also
among those who received commissions from other officers' training
camps. Thirteen were appointed
at about the same time as officers
in the Regular Army.
Thirteen Hopkins men are in the
Naval Militia, ten in the Naval
Reserve, three in the Maryland infantry, five in aviation and three
in the coast artillery. The Maryland Battalion of Field Artillery
has twenty-five J. H. U. men on
its roster. Nineteen are in the
Ambulance Corps. Several more
have entered different branches of
the Canadian and British armies.
THE NEWS-LETTER expects to
publish in an early issue as complete a list of the Johns Hopkins
men who have entered as it is possible to obtain at the present time.

at Anniston, Ala., where are also
Stuart Egerton and W. Jacobson.
Henry Evans, business manager,is
with an ambulance unit in France,
and Paul Wiggins, art editor, is in
the Officers' Reserve Corps. Only
Wolfe and Rothschild, the remaining members of the board, have returned to the University.
The Senior Class will probably
meet in the near future and take
some definite action in regard to a
class book. To organize an entirely
new business and editorial staff
at this late date seems highly improbable and most impracticable.
However, some substitute for the
Hullabaloo will more than likely
be adopted. It may be that a
much less elaborate book than the
traditional Hullabaloo will be approved, or it may be found possible to co-operate with THE NEWSLETTER in the publishing of the
most essential features of a Hullabaloo.

The organization of this year's
track team will take place at a
mass-meeting for athletics to be
held in the Civil Engineering
Building this Wednesday at 12.30
o'clock, at which time the plans
and prospects for one of the most
ambitious schedules the team has
ever had to carry out will be discussed by Coach Joseph T. England, Captain Firor and the
manager.
On the same day the fall practice will commence on Straus
Field at 5 o'clock. This will comprise cross country runs and preliminary work on the hurdles. The
cross country course has been completely laid out and flagged and
will be in good condition for use.
A big field day of fourteen regular
events is being planned as the
culmination of fall training.
The schedule starts off with the
S. A. A. cross country meet on
Thanksgiving Day. In it Hopkins
will probably compete with teams
representing Virginia, Washington and Lee, Virginia Polytechnic
Institute and Catholic University
of Washington, D. C. Georgetown
University may also enter men.
Following this will occur the
two Washington indoor meets—
those of George Washington and
Georgetown Universities. Also in
mid-winter the big Hopkins-Fifth
Regiment Armory meet will take
place, in which every man on the
squad has a chance to make good.
It is expected that the S. A. A.
outdoor meet will be held on
Homewood Field the first Friday
and Saturday in May, and plans
are being made accordingly. Trips
to Washington and Lee and Haverford are likewise under consideration.
In every meet there are to be
fourteen regular events and Hopkins must have three men for each
event. Men in the longer distances
are especially needed, but Coach
England and Captain Firor are
anxious to have a large turnout
for the other events as well.
Firor, who is a first-year Student in the Medical School, hie
discovered quite a number of valuable men in that department of the
University who expect to help out
when training begins.

Currin, a literal-minded young
reporter, had been assigned to
cover a town ball. Later the city
editor was going over his copy.
"Look here, Currin," he suddenly called out. "What do you mean
by writing here,'Among the beautiful girls was Councilman Oscar
Dodge'? He isn't a 'beautiful
girl,' you dub; he's only a fat old
fusser."
"I can't help that," responded
Currin dogedly; "that's where he
was."—Ex.

COACH MURPHY NOW IN ARMY;
MAY RETURN AT CLOSE OF WAR

B.Russell Murphy, who resigned
his position as athletic director at
Johns Hopkins last August,is now
a physical director in the National
Army, with the rank of captain,
and has been placed in charge of
all physical work at Camp Lee,
Petersburg, Va. He has charge of
the fostering and organization of
athletics of all sorts among the
men.
Associated with Captain Murphy
in this work is Lieut. Edward M.
Stuart, Hopkins '17.
As he is still under contract
with the Athletic Association, it
is expected that Captain Murphy
will, at the close of the war, return to the University and resume
his duties as athletic director.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 8, 1917.
The Duty of Every Student.

Ever,‘ student attending the
University this year has responsibilities and duties more pressing
than ever before. The situation
facing him is most eloquently and
cogently described in the message
of our president, appearing on the
first page of this paper. The student must realize that he is a member of a world-famed institution
which is playing an invaluable
part in helping the Government
to bring this war to a close. It
has given its biggest men and offered all its resources to the Goveminent. The foremost of those
who are directing this country's
destinies in this present crisis are
Hopkins alumni. Every nerve of
the University is straining to
bring about world peace.
A student should, therefore, first
feel proud to have his name upon
the rolls of this University, and
should have as his crowning ambition the desire to emulate those
Hopkins men who are giving their •
best to the service of the United
States. He should realize that it
is his duty to prepare himself for
present military service or for the
later period of reconstruction.
This is to be done by first mastering his studies, and then by build-

ing up • his physical welfare
through enlistment in the corps
and participation in athletics. He
should support also, as far as his
time and ability will permit, the
other activities. He must bend all
his energies to uphold the honor
and traditions of old Hopkins, and
the new responsibilities it has assumed as a leading war-time institution.

Camp Jackson is five miles out

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 8, 1917.
RESUMED

ROOTERS TO GO TO GETTYSBURG

Promotions on West Point Basis-220
Men Report — Provisional Officers
Appointed—Hopkins Rating Excellent—Konze Made Major.

Arrangements Made for Students to
Attend Game—Trip Through Historic
Grounds Planned — Special
Rates Secured.

The future policy of the Reserve
Officers' rraining Corps at Johns
Hopkins, with regard to promotions, will be along lines strictly
similar to that followed at West
Point, according to general orders
recently publishel through the adjutant by Captain Guild, the new
professor of military training and
tactics.
The West Point system is fundamentally based upon the division
of appointments, so that the commissioned officers are picked from
the Senior Class, the sergeants
from the juniors and the corporals
from the sophomores. Promotions
are strictly according to seniority
and efficiency. The appointments
made at the present time are provisional only, and will be retained
after December 15 only on proved
efficiency.
The following provisional appointments and assignments have
been made:
To be major—J. E. Konze.
Company A — Captain, C. H.
Baxley; first lieutenant, M. B.
Carroll; second lieutenant, N. S.
Cullum; first sergeant, L. W. Simon.
Company B — Captain, K. 0.
Bitter; first lieutenant, J. H.
Lampe; second lieutenant, H. H.
Startzman ; first sergeant, L. T.
mitt.
Company C — Captain, L. T.
Chisholm; first lieutenant, G. S.
Harris; second lieutenant, C. A.
Bryan; first sergeant, E. H. Townsend.
The non-commissioned personnel
has also been announced.
The first assembly of the corps
was held -last Thursday on the
quadrangle, when approximately
220 men reported. These will
eventually be divided into three
companies of 72 men each. A detachment of commissioned and
non-commissioned officers from the
three small companies of trained
men will be detailed as drill-masters for the new men.
Drills are set for Monday and
Thursday of each week, with optional drills to be held for the companie.; in rotation on Tuesdays.
The nature of the work taken up

Arrangements have been made
for every student of Johns Hopkins to accompany- the team to
the football game with Gettysburg
this coming Saturday. The train,
on the Western Maryland Railroad, leaves Union Station at 8
A. M., arriving in Gettysburg later
in the morning. Rooters will be
provided with banners, megaphones and other cheering paraphernalia.
Upon arrival, buses will be provided to convey all those who wish
to see the historic battleground to
the many points of interest, one being the encampment of the several
thousand soldiers who are stationed there. The majority of
these men are to attend the game.
This is the first time that Hopkins has played Gettysburg away
from Baltimore, and the contest
promises to be a good one. Special
rates have been obtained from the
railroad and the sightseeing cars
at Gettysburg, and a special admission price has been secured,
making the cost of the trip very
small.

MILITARY

TRAINING

at the latter drills will be at the
option of the students. It is expected that the work this year will
progress rapidly, hi view of the
fact that a much larger percentage
of the corps are trained men than
was the case last year.
It has been learned through an
authoritative source that the report made to the War Department
by the inspecting officer who reviewed the Hopkins troops last
spring was highly favorable. It
stated that the greatest spirit and
zeal were exhibited, that the requirements were more than met
and that the Johns Hopkins Reserve Officers' Training Corps compared more than favorably with
any in the country.
Capt. G. D. Guild, retired, the
new professor of military training
and tactics, graduated at West
Point in 1903, and was at one time
stationed in the regiment with his
predecessor here, Lieutenant Elliott, who is now serving as captain in the army.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 8, 1917.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.
All letters intended for publication must
be concise.
No attention will be paid to anonymous
letters, but names signed as an evidence of
good faith will not be printed if request is
made that they be omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to be
taken as an indorsement of its views by THE
NEWS-LETTER, which invites the freest discussion of matters of general interest.

Sophomores, Attention!
To the Editor of TIIE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—I wish to make a vigorous
protest against the attitude of the
undergraduate body of the University toward the obedience of
freshman regulations. No one
seems to know why, but there is
an indifference to all expressions
of college spirit at Hopkins this
year, which is drably discouraging. What has come over the student body? They are
they are asleep; they are dead!
And we are all being anaesthetized by that very indifference into
a dreamy state of I-should-worryness! As a result, here are the
freshmen sauntering in and out
of the main entrance to Gilman
Hall, walking across the campus,
wearing their hats with delightful
unconcern as to whether they are
indoors or out! Right now is the
time for deciding the question of
the responsibility for the enforcement of the regulations. The
trouble is that no one knows who
1$ supposed to enforce them; and
a responsibility not deliberately
and specifically imposed will not
be shouldered by anyone at'all. I
appeal to the loyalty and good
sense of the Sophomore Class to
take this matter in hand. If we
cannot make the pulse of Hopkins
spirit throb with a sense of new ••
life, we shall at least succeed in
giving the University the opportunity of copying a brand of genuine college spirit!
SOPHOMORE.
October 6, 1917.

MUSICAL CLUBS MEET TUESDAY SPIRIT SHOWN AT RECEPTION
Spieker, Will Lead Singing—Mandolin
Club Becomes Instrumental Club.
Two Out-of-Town Trips
Being Planned.

An organization meeting of the
Johns Hopkins Combined Musical
Clubs is to be held thisTuesday,
and practice will commence soon
afterwards. Manager Kellum is
trying to engage an outside man
to take charge of instruction of
the stringed instruments, and it is
hoped that a leader can be found

The Ballad of the Dean's Decree.
The Dean sent word to the students
That range the Homewood green,
And he made decree: "Give ear to me
And hearken to the Dean.
"Forbear to sleep in the gathering day
And cut your class the while;
No more let breakfast-food delay,
Nor buckwheat cakes beguile;
Nor think to loaf on all the profs,
While saying: 'I should smile.'
"Ye may weigh the down of a molting
gnat,
Or compass a comet's girth.
Determine the rule of the molecule,
Or the swing of the cycling earth.
If ye cut your class, ye shall not pass,
For what is your physics worth?

The announcement that a large
contingent of rooters could go by

The Debating Council will soon
be ready to announce the dates
and subjects of the debates for the
coming year, including the traditional triangular debate and the
interclass debate. It is quite possible that an extended trip may
be arranged for the collegiate debating team this year.
The University of Virginia, the
University of North Carolina and
Johns Hopkins University make
up the triangle which stages a
triple-ringed contest every spring.
Unfortunately, the triangular debate had to be cancelled last year
to clear the way for uninterrupted
military training. Up to that
time the Hopkins team had consistently brought home the trophy.
Incidentally, the gold "H" for intercollegiate debating is awarded
to the memebers of this team.
The annual interclass debate between the senior and junior classes
for the Adams prize will take
place this year before the Christmas vacation, in order that more
time may be given to intercollegiate debating.
If sufficient interest in debating
is shown among the freshmen, a
freshman team will be organized
and a freshman-sophomore debate
arranged.
